Topic.Title: Latest Barron's absolutely TRASHED Amazon's gross overvaluation, calls it "WORRISOMELY EXPENSIVE"

Message.Msg: "Who cares"? Investors should care. "Everybody knows that AMZN is an expensive stock"? Then why buy it? I would be especially worried about the forward PE estimates for next year, with the economy slowing. Acting like a 100 PE is a "bargain" when rivals sell for PEs less than 1/5th as large seems ridiculous. But what if the 100 PE never materializes. That is when Amazon does a Netflix-like dive imho.

Topic.Title: Fiscal cliff + worldwide recession + tax hike + online taxing.

Message.Msg: Capital gains rate increases on security gains are on the table. Whether its Erskine bowles to replace turbo timmy, we know the rates for the wealthy are gonna look like earned income. This will propel the rates from 15% to closer to 40% [not even including state income taxes]. so the wealthy are gonna vote with their feet before year end. This is why we are seeing the collapse of the momo stocks. Its just the beginning. We haven't even seen critical mass yet. This will turn into a regenerative feedback loop. Selling begats selling. Why do you think so many on wall street supported Rommney? Now Obama is gonna stick it in dry. momo stocks are toast. Pick the target at the shooting gallery....amazon being my personal favorite. when god give you lemmons, make lemmonade.

Topic.Title: A very serious question; no flaming, please.

Message.Msg: AMZN current assests less current liabilities has dropped from $2.6B at the start of the year to $0.5B last Q. With a current ratio at essentially 1, they are not going to be able to buy back the options to keep the share count flat. In fact, if this keeps up, they may have to do a secondary ... which would destroy the stock price.

Topic.Title: well, looks like everyone is here

Message.Msg: Thanks Cash. Good to see you here... Have to make a little more money first :-) And, have to build the track record a little more... Been right on several big wins (and a little earlier, but the brand of the big boys broke them), but anyone can get lucky a few times. I'm trying to prove out a slightly different model -- one where someone who writes/acts who provides analysis or advice actually puts a material portion of his/her wealth on the line. The entire model of playing with OPM is #$%$ and broken. If any of these sell side analysts were forced to have 25% of their wealth directed into companies they cover and unable to sell until price targets were achieved, not one would put ANY money into companies Amazon. By the way, a few of the plays we discussed earlier are getting ripe as well.

Topic.Title: A very serious question; no flaming, please.

Message.Msg: Generally, AMZN generates a ton of cash in Q4. But, with more of the sales being product being sold at cost (you don't really get the advantage of negative float on product you sell at cost...) and with the new monthly Prime (many people will sign up for monthly rather than annual before the holiday season), AMZN will lose a significant source of cash flow and digital content sales will take longer to ramp... I said awhile ago and I was completely serious that AMZN has spent like a drunken sailor and made itself vulnerable to a downturn. And yes, I mean raising capital (whether debt or equity) vulnerable. Cramer and his ilk bash GRPN, but its cost structure scales down better than AMZN's. Institutional longs would be very well served to sell here, buy there and reserve cash for GRPN for the future. It not only serves but dominates a more unique niche (and doesn't have Apple, Google and WalMart attacking it on every front)... But, no one invests anymore. It's all about trying to knock others out which actually perpetuates the malinvestment and misallocation of resources. And still they wonder why investors keep pulling money from the market...

Message.Title: When will Amazon file for bankruptcy?
Message.Msg: Their cash position relative to short tern liability is extremely dangerous. Since it is not profitable, it would be unable to issue debt. However, It can issue stock or preferred stock if market is still drinking kool aid at that time. Walmart can bankrupt amazon in 6 months if it decides to use its online to sell everything 10% lower than amazon. Walmart can easily take the loss, but not amazon.

Topic.Title: When will Amazon file for bankruptcy?

Message.Msg: WalMart will not have to do the heavy lifting. Amazon went directly after Apple's core business and opened a business model competition. Further, with its stupid anti-trust play on eBooks, it guaranteed that Apple can choose to sell eBooks at cost or even a loss (its loss leader versus AMZN's hardware loss leader), which given the immense number of iPads out there would hit Amazon's core source of cash flow VERY hard. That would be the nail in the coffin. Oh, and did I mention that Google doesn't like AMZN very much and can do the same on all Android and Chrome devices (Chromebooks are killing it right now... will show up soon). Open, cloud based eBooks standard will put AMZN into a world of hurt. WalMart and Best Buy matching prices on high value density items (where there is a store and service to support any problems) will create a selection bias in AMZN orders, pushing up shipping cost relative to item profit (and since shipping will be free for $7.99 a month Prime) will also hurt Amazon... Will be a fun year. Do not get impatient. Short responsibly or use on very LT puts...

Topic.Title: When will Amazon file for bankruptcy?

Message.Msg: Outside of a true financial shock, it is very unlikely there would be bankruptcy. It does generate cash from operations and could scale back all investment while raising debt or equity (albeit at lower prices than today by a significant margin). If there is a financial shock, then all bets are off. Amazon could literally be done. The malinvestment has made it very vulnerable to tail risk. Shorts must be patient. If you are buying November options, you like likely have your money taken. This will take months to play out...

Topic.Title: Petition to SECEDE from union

Message.Msg: Are you going to pay for the entire military complex that provides for your security and safety? No? There's an alternative. Move out of the country. Seriously. See how much you like living overseas if things get really ugly... For the record, blue states have tended to be net taxpayers while red states have been subsidized by the Federal government over the 20th century (during the period of global industrial and technology dominance, blue states bore a disproportionate share of the tax burden). Everyone has to grow the f' up. We are going to have to pay more taxes. We are going to have to cut spending, especially as it relates to entitlements. Out SOL as measured by consumption will fall and not in a small way. But, we will still be vastly better off than any other nation in the world. If you feel differently, then I encourage you to pack up and leave. The rest of us can focus on trying to put this country back on track...

This is nothing...

Message.Title: Sybs, short the builders at will if they cap deductions...
Message.Msg: I know you've been short the builders before. I never have, but I might even change my favorite short candidates if all the chatter on limiting deductions holds. I cannot think of a faster way to absolutely obliterate the "nascent" housing recovery than to essentially eliminate the mortgage interest deduction, which is what the proposed caps would effectively do for any home worth a few hundred thousand or more... It will affect the builders first new buyers will be willing to pay far less for homes in an era of capped mortgage interest deductions. But, it will ultimately kill existing homes sales and all real estate prices in the process... For all those that believe a compromise will make everything okay, you might want to start thinking of issues like this. The money is going to come from somewhere. In the proposed case, it will largely come from upper middle class and lower upper class families (but it will work out just fine for the .1% who could scale charitable giving back and would benefit from keeping the existing top rates on all income and for those who pay little to no tax today) compared to the default increases. I wonder what the compromise will do to consumption?... I guess this will have to stay my favorite short...

In fact, I think traders are undermining this country by sending distorted investment signals to business (self reinforcing technical driven trading has decoupled stock prices the underlying economics and leads to misallocation of resources). It penalizes productive investment (companies like INTC) and rewards unsustainable investment in already overbuilt domestic consumption (almost all MOMO companies are consumer facing in some way, AMZN, LULU, CMG, GMCR, etc etc)... Then again, no one seems to care how they make money anymore...
